Legal_Issue: Whether the citizenship judge erred in refusing the application based on residency
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed 1,098 days of physical presence but failed to provide sufficient evidence for all days
Decision_Outcome: Application rejected due to unproven residency
Defendant_Behavior: Insufficient documentation provided to prove physical presence
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error by citizenship judge in assessing residency
Legal_Standard: Physical presence requirement of 1,095 days within four years
Assessment_Factor: Credibility and sufficiency of residency documentation
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from citizenship judge to Federal Court
Credibility_Assessment: Judge found discrepancies in documentation affecting credibility
Evidence_Used: Residency records, application forms, supporting documents
Application_Basis: Naturalization through fulfillment of residency requirement
Evidence_Assessed: Days of claimed physical presence in Canada
Governing_Rule: Applicant must prove 1,095 days of physical presence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to substantiate all claimed days of residence
Decisional_Body: Citizenship Judge, reviewed by Federal Court
Harm_Assessment: No harm established; decision upheld as reasonable
Cause_Description: Inability to prove required physical presence in Canada
Evidence_Handling: Documentation assessed for completeness and consistency
Evidence_Issues: Discrepancies and lack of sufficient proof for claimed days
Evidence_Assessment: Critical evaluation of applicant's evidence on residency
Decision_Rationale: No legal or factual errors found in the judge's assessment
Evidentiary_Issues: Insufficient and inconsistent evidence provided by applicant
